4.Five-year accident history. 

There have been no releases of Vinyl Acetate Monomer (VAM) in the past five years that have had an adverse impact on the community. 

5. The emergency response program. 

This facility's written emergency response program is based on the requirements of the Environmental Protection Agency, United States Coast Guard, Department of Transportation, Occupational Safety and Health Administration and Local Emergency Planning Commission. The emergency response program includes procedures for notification of the local fire and police authorities and notification of any potentially affected neighbors. This plan has been submitted to and approved by the respective regulatory agencies and is reviewed on an annual basis. The facility is subject to regular annual inspections by each of the aforementioned governmental agencies.

Employees are trained and prepared to respond to emergencies.  Training includes Emergency Response (HAZWOPER), Emergency Action and Fire Prevention, Accidental Release Prevention, Environmental Awareness, and Terminal Safety Systems.  Emergency Response Team (ERT) members also attend fire school at Texas A&M University.  These are both initial and annual refresher as applicable. 

Finally, the facility prepares for emergencies by conducting quarterly notification drills, semi-annual equipment deployment drills, annual tabletop exercises, and participates in area-wide drills that are conducted by governmental agencies.   

6. Planned changes to improve safety. 

This facility was constructed in 1953 and is in compliance with applicable governmental and industry standards. No changes are planned to upgrade the facility.  Kinder Morgan  has a commitment to continuous improvement of our safety program.  As su

1. Accidental release prevention and emergency response policies:

KM Liquids Terminals LLC (KMLT) - Pasadena Terminal is a petroleum and chemical products storage and distribution facility. This Facility is regulated under 40 CFR Part 68 due to the presence of Vinyl Acetate Monomer (VAM) in quantities exceeding the identified threshold amount. VAM has been identified by EPA as a potentially toxic substance and as such, it is necessary to observe certain safety precautions in handling VAM to prevent unnecessary human exposure, to reduce the threat to employee personal health, and to reduce the threat to nearby members of the community. It is the policy of KMLT to adhere to all applicable Federal and state rules and regulations. Safety depends upon the manner in which the regulated substance is handled and employees are trained combined with engineered safeguards inherent to the system.

Pasadena Terminal maintains a written emergency response program based on the EPA, Coast Guard, DOT, OSHA and LEPC requirements. The emergency response plan includes procedures for notification of the local fire authority and notification of any potentially affected neighbors. 

2. The stationary source and regulated substances handled. 

The regulated substance handled at this Facility is Vinyl Acetate Monomer (VAM). VAM is used as a raw material for manufacturing polyvinyl resins such as those used in latex paints, paper coating, adhesives, textile finishing, and safety glass interlayers. VAM is received by barge and stored in two storage tanks.  VAM is distributed to a single customer via pipeline. This facility has equipment for unloading ships, barges, rail cars and tank trucks of other materials. Access to the site is restricted to authorized facility employees, authorized management personnel and authorized contractors. 

3. The general accidental release prevention program and the specific prevention steps.
